title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 14 or 15 [february 1870]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 14 or 15 [February 1870]
text: Feb â€” 1871tuesdayTuesday 14 well walterWalter dearwe are permitted to see another rainy day but rather warm i am so glad waltWalt to hear you say you are so well i got your letter to day and the book came all safe i was very glad to have it i have read it partly through and like it very much i stay at home so much that i want something to read i shall show georgeGeorgey the letter about the interest he always gives me some money when he comes but he has had so much to pay every time he has been home that i didentdidn't ask him for as much as i should if he hadenthadn't had so much to pay the taxes was i think 180 dollerdollars and he has to have money to pay his expencesexpenses walterWalter you go around so much you must get some new clothsclothes i think that gray satinet would make you a couple of pairs of pantaloons and vest but i dontdon't think you would like it for a coat i think the pantaloons should be lined with thin muslin walterWalter i gessguess you dontdon't want to see me more than i doodo you) i have just been reading about vanvoriesVorhees the ex supervisor that was shot sundaySunday night in south brooklynBrooklyn you will see it i suppose in the papers) i am glad you wrote to han and sent her the harpersHarper's i get it every saturdaySaturday) you must tell me when you write how many valentines you gotgood by my dear walterWalteri haventhaven't heard from st louisSt. Louis Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 14 or 15 [February 1870]
